docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for doctors and hospitals said yesterday that the Cigna Corporation was understating its potential liability from an agreement to settle claims that it had unfairly reduced or denied insurance payments for medical care. Plaintiffs' lawyers said that the cost to Cigna would exceed $200 million, based on what the case disclosed about disputed billing practices. Lawyers for the plaintiffs could receive $36 million under the settlement.

headline.main: Cigna's Cost In Settlement Is Disputed By Plaintiffs

docs.abstract: Lawyers for doctors and hospitals say Cigna Corp is understating its potential liability from agreement to settle claims that it had unfairly reduced or denied insurance payments for medical care; plaintiffs' lawyers say cost to Cigna would exceed $200 million; lawyer for plaintiffs could receive $36 million under settlement; Cigna says its payments would be much smaller; settlement allows 600,000 to 700,000 doctors to apply for payments of charges that had been automatically reduced since 1996 by software program Cigna used; Cigna hopes settlement will bar most claims against it in class-action suit filed in Miami against eight health insurance companies; Federal Judge Federico Moreno on Dec 3 will consider challenge to Illinois settlement by lawyers for doctors and medical groups, who say it is too weak (M)
docs.snippet: Lawyers for doctors and hospitals said yesterday that the Cigna Corporation was understating its potential liability from an agreement to settle claims that it had unfairly reduced or denied insurance payments for medical care.    Plaintiffs' lawyers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal regulators yesterday approved the nation's top-selling allergy drug, Claritin, as an over-the-counter medicine, a decision that will bring substantial savings for the uninsured and allow all patients to obtain the drug without a trip to the doctor. The decision will raise costs for many allergy patients with insurance, however, because insurers will no longer cover most of the cost of Claritin.

headline.main: CLARITIN TO SELL OVER THE COUNTER

docs.abstract: Federal regulators approve nation's top-selling allergy drug, Claritin, as an over-the-counter medicine, decision that will bring substantial savings for uninsured and allow all patients to obtain drug without trip to doctor; decision will raise costs for many allergy patients with insurance, however, because insurers will no longer cover most of cost of Claritin; insured patients may also now pay more for other allergy medicines because some insurers say they plan to require co-payments as high as $50 for remaining prescription anti-histamines--Clarinex, Allegra and Zyrtec--to prompt patients to take Claritin instead; photo; chart (M)
docs.snippet: Federal regulators yesterday approved the nation's top-selling allergy drug, Claritin, as an over-the-counter medicine, a decision that will bring substantial savings for the uninsured and allow all patients to obtain the drug without a trip to the...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Inspections Begin in Iraq; No Resistance Reported United Nations arms inspectors made their first field forays in Iraq, checking three sites for traces of illegal weaponry with no reported resistance from the Iraqis, officials said. A1 White House Woos Turkey The Bush administration is mounting a major effort to enlist the support of the new Islamic government of Turkey for a northern front if there is a war with Iraq. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, the heart surgeon who helped reclaim the Senate for the Republicans, is plunging into his next political challenge, one fraught with risks and opportunities for his president and his party: overhauling Medicare, the popular -- and costly -- health insurance program for the elderly. Most Republicans are keenly aware that they need to deliver prescription drug benefits to the nation's elderly in the next two years. They have repeatedly promised to do so and now control both Congress and the White House. Democrats, who assert that the Republicans simply paid lip service to the issue to get through the elections, are certain to hold them accountable if they fail.

headline.main: Republican Senator Fixes on Overhaul of Medicare as His Next Mission

docs.abstract: Sen Bill Frist focuses on need to overhaul Medicare, health insurance program for elderly and disabled, interview; says more is needed than simply adding drug benefit; admits he probably wants to go further than Republican Party leadership; photo (M)a

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation said today that it would take a fourth-quarter charge of up to $65 million to settle a dispute with doctors claiming the insurer cheated them out of reimbursements. Cigna said the tentative settlement of the federal class-action lawsuit would lead to an after-tax charge of $50 million to $65 million in the current quarter to pay for insurance related to the settlement.

headline.main: Cigna to Take Quarterly Charge To Cover Class-Action Lawsuit

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp will take up to $65 million fourth-quarter charge to settle dispute with nearly 300,000 doctors, hospitals and others who claim insurer cheated them out of reimbursements; admits no wrongdoing; court gives preliminary approval to settlement (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Nov. 25 front-page article about the uninsured middle class didn't examine a major political obstacle to comprehensive and affordable health care coverage for all Americans: the power of insurance companies to thwart legislation by influencing lawmakers through large campaign contributions and by using the media to distort the means and goals of any sweeping health insurance plan.

headline.main: Health Care Takes a Bigger Bite

docs.abstract: Sam Ludu letter contends Nov 25 article did not address major political obstacle to affordable health care coverage: powerful lobbying by insurance companies

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Problem of Lost Health Benefits Is Reaching Into the Middle Class'' (front page, Nov. 25) describes the solutions proposed in Congress and elsewhere to deal with the impending health care crisis as, essentially, either (a) to provide tax breaks to companies to cover health insurance or (b) to extend Medicaid benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Health care is an economic commodity, just like food, clothing, housing and entertainment. But unlike other commodities where the cost is paid directly by the consumer, third-party health insurance creates a supply-driven system with little incentive for comparison shopping or common-sense consideration of access.

headline.main: Health Care Takes a Bigger Bite

docs.abstract: Stefani Daniels letter holds third-party health insurance system creates supply-driven system with little incentive for comparison shopping or consideration of access (Nov 25 article)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Problem of Lost Health Benefits Is Reaching Into the Middle Class'' (front page, Nov. 25): I am disheartened that Congress's newfound interest in the health care problem is a result of the fact that being uninsured is no longer a ''problem chiefly of the poor and the unemployed.'' I sympathize with one uninsured woman's ''humiliating'' experience when she took her daughter to the doctor. But I wonder if her humiliation was a result of not being able to pay the doctor or a result of feeling the social stigma that has been attached to being uninsured.

headline.main: Health Care Takes a Bigger Bite

docs.abstract: Tina Hardin letter on Nov 25 article on health insurance says most social problems fail to gain interest from public and government until they begin to reach into largely nonminority middle class
